intro: Fumaria parviflora var. persica, commonly known as Persian celandine, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and western Asia. It is a member of the Papaveraceae family, characterized by its delicate, yellow-orange flowers and lance-shaped leaves. The plant typically grows in shaded, moist environments such as woodland floors or along stream banks. Its flowers bloom in early spring, and the plant produces capsule fruits that contain numerous small, dark seeds. The leaves and stems are often covered in fine, silky hairs, which contribute to its distinctive appearance.
